unnormalised: Breaking News: AIIMS Delhi sees surge in young patients diagnosed with early-stage cancer.
normalised: Breaking News: A-I-I-M-S Delhi sees surge in young patients diagnosed with early-stage cancer.

unnormalised: New Delhi: AIIMS Delhi reported a worrying trend this week, with oncologists observing a noticeable increase in patients under 40 being diagnosed with various forms of cancer. Dr. Rajiv Kumar, Head of Oncology at AIIMS, stated, "We've seen a 25% rise in cases amongst young adults in the last 6 months alone. This is alarming." While the exact causes are still under investigation, factors like lifestyle changes, environmental pollution, and genetic predispositions are suspected. Many are consulting Dr. Sharma's clinic, which is located near gate no. 3 of AIIMS.
normalised: New Delhi: A-I-I-M-S Delhi reported a worrying trend this week, with oncologists observing a noticeable increase in patients under forty being diagnosed with various forms of cancer. Doctor Rajiv Kumar, Head of Oncology at A-I-I-M-S, stated, "We've seen a twenty five percent rise in cases amongst young adults in the last six months alone. This is alarming." While the exact causes are still under investigation, factors like lifestyle changes, environmental pollution, and genetic predispositions are suspected. Many are consulting Doctor Sharma's clinic, which is located near gate number three of A-I-I-M-S.

unnormalised: The most prevalent types of cancer detected in this age group are breast cancer, cervical cancer, and lymphomas. Symptoms often go unnoticed or are dismissed as minor ailments until the disease reaches a more advanced stage. Ms. Aisha Khan, a 32-year-old patient recently diagnosed with stage 2 breast cancer, shared her experience, "I initially ignored the lump thinking it was just hormonal changes. By the time I consulted a doctor, it was already quite advanced." Aisha's story echoes the experiences of many others.
normalised: The most prevalent types of cancer detected in this age group are breast cancer, cervical cancer, and lymphomas. Symptoms often go unnoticed or are dismissed as minor ailments until the disease reaches a more advanced stage. Miss Aisha Khan, a thirty two year old patient recently diagnosed with stage two breast cancer, shared her experience, "I initially ignored the lump thinking it was just hormonal changes. By the time I consulted a doctor, it was already quite advanced." Aisha's story echoes the experiences of many others.

unnormalised: Dr. Kumar emphasized the importance of early detection, urging individuals to undergo regular check-ups and screenings. "Annual health screenings, especially for individuals with a family history of cancer, are crucial. Early detection significantly improves treatment outcomes," he advised. He also mentioned that a new clinical trial for advanced lung cancer patients will begin on 15/11/2024. The hospital aims to provide cutting-edge treatment options and improve survival rates.
normalised: Doctor Kumar emphasized the importance of early detection, urging individuals to undergo regular check-ups and screenings. "Annual health screenings, especially for individuals with a family history of cancer, are crucial. Early detection significantly improves treatment outcomes," he advised. He also mentioned that a new clinical trial for advanced lung cancer patients will begin on fifteenth November two thousand and twenty four. The hospital aims to provide cutting-edge treatment options and improve survival rates.

unnormalised: AIIMS Delhi is working closely with the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare to launch awareness campaigns aimed at educating the public about cancer prevention and early detection. This includes providing information on healthy lifestyles, risk factors, and available screening facilities. The campaigns will target urban and rural populations, using various media channels to reach a wider audience. A dedicated helpline (1800-11-1234) has also been set up to provide information and support to cancer patients and their families.
normalised: A-I-I-M-S Delhi is working closely with the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare to launch awareness campaigns aimed at educating the public about cancer prevention and early detection. This includes providing information on healthy lifestyles, risk factors, and available screening facilities. The campaigns will target urban and rural populations, using various media channels to reach a wider audience. A dedicated helpline (one eight hundred hyphen eleven hyphen one two three four) has also been set up to provide information and support to cancer patients and their families.

unnormalised: The rising incidence of cancer among young adults is a pressing concern, demanding immediate attention and concerted efforts from healthcare professionals, policymakers, and the public. Further research is needed to fully understand the underlying causes and develop effective prevention strategies. The next Oncology Dept. meeting is scheduled for 10:00 AM on 28/07/2024.
normalised: The rising incidence of cancer among young adults is a pressing concern, demanding immediate attention and concerted efforts from healthcare professionals, policymakers, and the public. Further research is needed to fully understand the underlying causes and develop effective prevention strategies. The next Oncology Department meeting is scheduled for ten AM on twenty eighth July two thousand and twenty four.
